title: Targeted Poverty Alleviation Campaign
summary: China's Targeted Poverty Alleviation campaign, launched by Xi Jinping in 2013, deployed 255,000 work teams and invested over $246 billion to lift 98.99 million rural poor above the poverty line by 2021, de-listing all 832 nationally designated poor counties.
content:
## Background

China's economic reforms since 1978 had already produced the most dramatic poverty reduction in human history, with over 700 million people escaping poverty between 1978 and 2012 according to World Bank estimates. However, by the early 2010s, the remaining poverty was concentrated among populations facing structural disadvantages: ethnic minorities in remote mountainous areas, people with disabilities, the elderly, and communities in ecologically fragile environments where conventional development strategies had limited reach.

The national poverty line stood at 2,300 yuan per person per year in 2010 constant prices, roughly equivalent to the World Bank's $1.90 per day international poverty line at purchasing power parity. By 2012, an estimated 98.99 million people in rural China still lived below this threshold, concentrated in 832 nationally designated poor counties, predominantly in western and central provinces including Guizhou, Yunnan, Gansu, and Tibet.

Previous poverty reduction programs had relied heavily on broad-based economic growth and regional development initiatives. While effective at reducing mass poverty, these approaches had diminishing returns for the remaining hard-core poor, who required more individualized and targeted interventions. Recognition of this challenge prompted a fundamental strategic shift.

## The Intervention

In November 2013, President Xi Jinping introduced the concept of "targeted poverty alleviation" (jingzhun fupin) during a visit to Hunan Province. The approach represented a departure from previous area-based strategies, emphasizing identification of individual poor households, diagnosis of specific causes of poverty, and tailored interventions for each case. The campaign was elevated to a top national political priority, with Xi personally chairing the Central Leading Group for Poverty Alleviation.

The operational machinery was massive. Some 255,000 work teams comprising approximately 3 million cadres were dispatched to all 128,000 registered poor villages. Each poor household was assigned a responsible official who conducted assessments and developed household-specific plans. Five main pathways out of poverty were identified: industrial development (supporting local enterprises and agriculture), labor transfer (skills training and job placement), ecological compensation (payments for environmental services), education support, and social security guarantees.

For the most geographically isolated populations, the campaign undertook the relocation of 9.6 million people from areas deemed uninhabitable to newly constructed resettlement communities with access to services and employment. Total fiscal expenditure exceeded 1.6 trillion yuan (approximately $246 billion), combining central and local government funds, with significant additional resources mobilized through directed lending, corporate partnerships, and e-commerce initiatives.

## Results & Evidence

China officially declared victory over absolute poverty on February 25, 2021, announcing that all 98.99 million registered poor had been lifted above the poverty line and all 832 poor counties had been de-listed. Infrastructure improvements were substantial: rural roads were extended to connect all previously isolated villages, safe housing was secured for all registered poor households, and access to education and healthcare was expanded significantly.

Alkire and Shen (2022), using the Multidimensional Poverty Index framework, confirmed substantial reductions in multiple dimensions of deprivation beyond income, including education, health, and living standards. Their analysis found that China's multidimensional poverty rate fell dramatically, with particularly strong improvements in housing quality, access to clean cooking fuel, and sanitation.

However, independent assessment faces limitations due to restricted data access. The poverty line remains low by middle-income country standards; the World Bank estimated that 13% of China's population remained below the $5.50 per day upper-middle-income poverty line as of 2019. Concerns about data reliability have been raised, as the high-stakes political nature of the campaign created incentives for local officials to report favorable results.

## Challenges & Criticisms

Sustainability is the foremost concern. Many of the interventions relied on continuous fiscal transfers, subsidized employment, and administrative support that may not be maintained indefinitely. The 9.6 million relocated people face challenges of social integration, employment stability, and cultural dislocation. Research by Li et al. (2020) found that some relocated communities experienced difficulties in adapting to new livelihoods, with former farmers struggling to transition to wage employment.

The campaign's top-down mobilization approach, while effective in achieving numerical targets, raised concerns about local agency and participatory development. Formalism and bureaucratic burden were acknowledged challenges, with reports of excessive paperwork and inspection requirements imposed on village-level cadres. The relative neglect of urban poverty and the situation of migrant workers who fall outside the rural household registration system represent significant gaps in the poverty reduction framework.

## Key Lessons

- Household-level targeting and individualized poverty diagnostics can address residual hard-core poverty that broad-based growth alone cannot reach.
- Massive bureaucratic mobilization can achieve rapid results when backed by top-level political commitment and substantial fiscal resources.
- Relocation programs must integrate livelihood support, community building, and cultural sensitivity to ensure sustainable outcomes.
- Political incentives tied to poverty targets risk data manipulation and focus on measurable indicators at the expense of harder-to-quantify dimensions of well-being.
- Sustained poverty reduction requires addressing structural inequalities, including urban-rural divides and the hukou system, beyond targeted campaigns.

## References

- Li, Y., Westlund, H., & Liu, Y. (2020). "Why Some Rural Areas Decline while Some Others Not: An Overview of Rural Evolution in the World." *Journal of Rural Studies*, 68, 135-145.
- World Bank. (2022). *Poverty and Shared Prosperity 2022: Correcting Course*. Washington, DC: World Bank.
- Rogers, S. (2014). "Betting on the Strong: Local Government Resource Allocation in China's Poverty Counties." *Journal of Rural Studies*, 36, 197-206.
